{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Swan-necked flask experiment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgq3p","text":"Agar in flask is sterilized","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7pj6k","text":"Flask is either left alone and no bacteria grow in it, or it is shaken so the liquid comes into contact with the next and it putrifies","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The organism must be found only in diceased organisms","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e8g78","text":"The organism should be isolated from the diseased organism","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ehf6","text":"The isolated organism can cause the disease in a new organism","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aonu","text":"The same microorganism can be isolated from the newly infected organism.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Straight chain (unbranched hydrocarbons)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbq85","text":"Head group is glycerol linked by ester bonds","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48rkk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Archaea always have ether linked phospholipids","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":20,"length":5,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"442da","text":"Side chains are composed of branched isoprene polymers","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be29d","text":"Some times the two lipid bilayers are covalently linked at the ends of the hydrocarbons into a monolayer.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Ether bonds are more stable","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6j2u","text":"Isoprene allows interactions at higher temperatures","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a5nj3","text":"They are less leaky to ions","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

They bind and inhibit transpeptidases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":11,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95l6d","text":"Resistance is conferred using:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25va","text":"Beta-lactamases","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vage","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h5cm","text":"Vancomycin the end of the peptide precursor.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":10,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"coe81","text":"Resistance is confered by changing the end of the precursor.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Found only in gram positive bacteria","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26urj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Found only in gram negative bacteria","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c95e3","text":"Contains lipopolysaccharide and proteins","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ec9fi","text":"LPS is also called endotoxin","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":19,"length":9,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Can be found in both gram positive and negative bacteria","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Secreted glycoproteins that form a protective slime","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Two strains of bacteria are used to infect mice","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1v7v3","text":"The rough strain is non-virulent","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qf23","text":"The smooth strain is virulent and causes disease","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kpob","text":"However","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebajh","text":"Heat-killed smooth cells are not virulent (neither are heat killed rought cells)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fd67","text":"However, heat-killed smooth cells mixed with viable rough cells are virulent.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Transforming principle purified and subjected to:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l4ud","text":"RNase or proteases: Transformation still occurs","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62a5r","text":"DNase: No transformation occurs","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adaon","text":"Therefore the transforming principle must be DNA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Bacteria are infected with bacteriophages containing either radioactive DNA or radioactive protein.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57nnm","text":"Afterwards they are fractionated into a bacterial fraction and a medium/virus fraction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ea27","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"580ob","text":"If DNA: The pellet (bacterial fraction) is radioactive.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e8kr","text":"If protein: The supernatant is radioactive but the pellet is not.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":12,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"nA = nT and nG = nC","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"o133","text":"Except in some viruses carrying single stranded genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Always contain double stranded DNA","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fonk1","text":"Are essential for viability","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnef","text":"Are in all bacterial species","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcnue","text":"Usually but not always circular","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etiii","text":"Usually but not always just one","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8v79","text":"Size: ~600-8000 kb","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":6,"length":12,"key":0}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Always contain double stranded DNA","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7do1q","text":"Are not essential for host viability (but often beneficial)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":4,"length":3,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jk4c","text":"Are not in all bacterial species","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":4,"length":3,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dcrsv","text":"Usually but not always circular","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b937","text":"Size: ~20-400 kb","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":6,"length":10,"key":0}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The 3'-OH of the previous nucleotide attacks the alpha-phosphate of the new nucleotide","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cr6fp","text":"Pyrophosphate is cleaved off and a bond is formed","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67nls","text":"Pyrophosphate is rapidly degraded by pyrophosphatase (this helps drive the reaction)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"DnaA recognizes the origin of replication which melts the DNA nearby","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":4,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":5,"length":63,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"6pli2","text":"DnaB is the helicase that is loaded to the newly meltet area","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":4,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":5,"length":55,"key":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8niv6","text":"DnaC is the helicase loader","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":4,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":5,"length":22,"key":2}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}},"1":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}},"2":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}}}}

front.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"42l5g","text":"What makes up the RNA polymerase core enzyme (in prokaryotes)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

back.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"2 alpha subunits","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8g9el","text":"1 beta subunit","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"854q4","text":"1 beta prime subunit","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

front.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"42l5g","text":"What makes up the RNA polymerase holoenzyme (in prokaryotes)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

back.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The holoenzyme consists of the core enzyme:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"age2d","text":"2 alpha subunits","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jmts","text":"1 beta subunits","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6ms2","text":"1 beta prime subunit","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4ujf","text":"As well as a sigma factor","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":13,"length":12,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

front.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"42l5g","text":"How does transcription initiation take place in prokaryotes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

back.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The polymerase scans for promotor sequences","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ajiq5","text":"The polymerase binds to the DNA","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ermj2","text":"The polymerase begins polymerizing and the sigma factor leaves the complex.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"A -10 region and a -35 region","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Two ways:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hsp9","text":"Rho independent termination: Where a stem loop is formed in the mRNA pulling it away from the polymerase.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":28,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63gb9","text":"Rho-dependent termination: Rho protein detects mRNA that is not covered by ribosome and coils it up, pulling it out of the polymerase.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":26,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5us6e","text":"This happens because of co-transcriptional translation. mRNA downstream of the stop codon is not translated and not protected from Rho like the ORF mRNA is.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"It's a 184 nucleotide long piece of RNA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n9q4","text":"It structurally mimicks a transcription bouble and binds the RNA polymerase","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The last base of the codon pairs loosely with the first base of the anticodon, which allows the tRNA to recognize multiple bases in the last position of the codon.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The 3'-OH of the acceptor stem","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"The small subunit (size: 30S) bind to the ribosome binding site","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":25,"length":3,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"4nbhg","text":"The initiator tRNA binds","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d35fc","text":"The large subunit (size 50S) binds","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":24,"length":3,"key":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e3ceu","text":"Translation begins","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eiodm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}},"1":{"type":"reveal","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Through basepairing between the 3'-end of the 16S rRNA and the mRNA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

front.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"42l5g","text":"What is the wobble-hypothesis at the initation codon.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":37,"length":15,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

back.richTextContent: {"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"It's reversed. The tRNA can recognize multiple bases for the first base of the codon (third of the anticodon).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Ribosome release factor 1 or 2 enter the site and release the peptide","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5i69d","text":"Ribosome release factor 3 allows freeing the ribosome and the first two release factors from the mRNA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"Two transcription factors: Lac repressor and CRP (cyclic AMP response protein)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2o2sg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ujfb","text":"Low lactose - low glucose: LacR binds, CRP binds - No transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":43,"length":6,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fgmt","text":"High lactose - low glucose: LacR is absent, CRP binds - Transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":33,"length":8,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":48,"length":6,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"un6f","text":"High lactose - high glucose: LacR is absent, CRP is absent - No transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":34,"length":8,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6q07b","text":"Low lactore - high glucose: LacR binds, CRP is absent - No transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":53,"length":1,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"In the presense of arginine, arginine biosynthetic genes are not expressed because the ArgR binds the DNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"No maltose - MaltA does not bind and no transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdee1","text":"Maltose - MaltA binds and transcription takes place","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"A Group of operons regulated by a common transcriptional repressor or activator.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9g866","text":"A ligand is bound to component one of the receptor","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak44s","text":"The receptor is phosphorylated","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1260l","text":"The receptor transfers the phosphorylation to an intracellular transcription factor (component 2)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
